reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s “abundance + diminishing returns” consideration (2.3.2). That consideration is not central to the overall argument (the essay already concludes WAM-convergence is unlikely and treats 2.3.2 as only weakly optimistic), so centrality is modest. The critique’s main point—that billionaire giving is a poor empirical anchor across a post-AGI phase shift and that new self-oriented, near-linear utility channels could prevent an altruism shift—is largely already anticipated in the position (it explicitly notes linear/selfish preferences, weak wealth–altruism correlation, and says the argument is not strong). So it adds limited refutational force beyond what’s “priced in,” yielding low strength. Most claims are plausible and directionally correct, though it overstates by implying the essay relies heavily on this lever or lacks any causal story at all (the essay does gesture at marginal utility reasoning and countervailing mechanisms). The critique is clear, tightly focused on one issue, and contains little dead weight.
title: Experience-expansion technologies could create linear selfish utility channels that block altruistic spending
